snippet: Along with the many funerals of the war in Syria, there are guilt-ridden weddings, and births, with new arrivals sometimes taking on the names of the departed.
abstract: Residents of Syria have learned to go on with life despite the conflict that has stretched on for nearly a year and a half; along with the many funerals, there are guilt-ridden weddings, and births, with new arrivals sometimes taking on the names of the departed.

byline.original: By an EMPLOYEE of THE NEW YORK TIMES in SYRIA and DAMIEN CAVE
byline.contributor: An employee of The New York Times reported from Aleppo, and Damien Cave from Beirut, Lebanon. Dalal Mawad contributed reporting from Beirut and Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

lead_paragraph: Along with the many funerals of the war in Syria, there are guilt-ridden weddings, and births, with new arrivals sometimes taking on the names of the departed.

headline.seo: Syrians Try to Balance Life’s Desires With War’s Demands
headline.main: Syrians Try to Balance Desires of Life With the Demands of a Growing War
headline.print_headline: Syrians Try to Balance Desires of Life With the Demands of a Growing War

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
keywords.name: subject
